actualResults.title: Missing Secure Flag on Session Cookie
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. This is a legitimate security misconfiguration where session cookies lack the Secure flag, allowing transmission over HTTP and making them vulnerable to network interception attacks. This is a distinct vulnerability not covered in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Username Enumeration via Error Messages and Response Behavior
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. The application reveals valid vs invalid usernames through different response behaviors (HTTP 302 redirect for valid, HTTP 200 with error for invalid). This enables username enumeration attacks not covered in expected findings.

actualResults.title: Username Enumeration via Password Page Response Discrepancy
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. Another username enumeration vector through direct access to password pages, returning HTTP 200 for valid usernames and HTTP 302 redirect for invalid ones. Distinct from the login form enumeration.

actualResults.title: Username Enumeration via Response Status Code Difference
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. Similar to previous but focuses specifically on HTTP status code discrepancies as the enumeration vector. Valid finding documenting another aspect of the username enumeration vulnerability.

actualResults.title: Missing SameSite Attribute on Session Cookie (CSRF Risk)
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. The absence of SameSite attribute on session cookies creates CSRF vulnerability across the entire application. This is a critical security misconfiguration enabling cross-site request forgery attacks.

actualResults.title: Default Credentials Allow Complete Authentication Bypass
actualResults.location: HTML comment disclosure and test account (test:test)
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. Extremely serious finding - default credentials (test:test) are publicly disclosed in HTML comments and remain active, allowing anyone to authenticate. This represents a complete authentication bypass and is a critical vulnerability.

actualResults.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) on Logout Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. The logout endpoint lacks CSRF protection, allowing attackers to force users to logout. While lower severity than other CSRF attacks, this is still a legitimate vulnerability with potential for attack chaining.

actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. The application lacks critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, Content-Security-Policy, X-Content-Type-Options, etc.) that provide defense-in-depth protection. This weakens overall security posture.

actualResults.title: User ID Disclosure in Hidden Form Fields
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. Internal database user_id values are exposed in hidden form fields, facilitating reconnaissance and IDOR testing. While low severity, this is poor security practice and aids attackers.

actualResults.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) on Login Form
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. Both steps of the authentication process lack CSRF tokens, enabling login CSRF attacks where victims can be logged into attacker-controlled accounts.

actualResults.title: Concurrent Session Vulnerability - No Session Invalidation on New Login
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. Multiple concurrent sessions are allowed without invalidating old sessions, preventing users from effectively revoking compromised sessions by logging in again.

actualResults.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Protection Missing on Password Reset Form
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. Password change functionality lacks CSRF protection, allowing attackers to change victim passwords through CSRF attacks. This is a serious vulnerability enabling account takeover.

actualResults.title: Two-Step Authentication Bypass via Direct URL Access
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. The two-step authentication flow can be bypassed by directly accessing step 2 without completing step 1, undermining the security model and simplifying automated attacks.

actualResults.title: Improper Error Handling Facilitates Order ID Enumeration
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. The endpoint returns HTTP 200 for non-existent orders (with empty content) instead of HTTP 404, enabling efficient order ID enumeration. This amplifies the impact of the IDOR vulnerability.

actualResults.title: Missing Rate Limiting on Password Reset Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. No rate limiting on password reset endpoint allows unlimited username enumeration and brute force attempts without throttling or detection.

actualResults.title: Missing Account Lockout Mechanism Allows Unlimited Brute Force Attempts
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. Critical authentication vulnerability - unlimited password attempts are possible without account lockout, enabling unrestricted brute force attacks. POC demonstrated 10 failed attempts followed by immediate successful login.

actualResults.title: No Session Timeout Configured - Sessions Never Expire
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. Sessions remain valid indefinitely without timeout, increasing the window for session hijacking attacks and preventing automatic invalidation of compromised sessions.

actualResults.title: Missing Rate Limiting Enables Brute Force Attacks on Authentication
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. Comprehensive finding documenting the complete absence of rate limiting on authentication endpoints, enabling large-scale brute force and credential stuffing attacks.

actualResults.title: Session Hijacking Possible via Cookie Theft (No Additional Protections)
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. Application lacks session binding mechanisms (IP validation, user-agent checking), allowing stolen session cookies to be used from any context without detection.

actualResults.title: Weak Password Policy Allows Trivial Passwords
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery. No password complexity requirements are enforced - the test account uses a 4-character password 'test' with no validation for length, complexity, or strength, enabling trivial brute force attacks.

matched.expectedTitle: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) in Order Receipts
matched.actualTitle: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) in Order Receipt Endpoint
matched.matchReason: This is a direct match of the expected IDOR vulnerability. Both describe the same issue: missing authorization checks on the order receipt endpoint allowing authenticated users to access other users' order receipts by manipulating the order_id parameter. The actual finding provided comprehensive evidence through POC testing, demonstrating that user 'test' (who owns orders 300123, 300214, 300327, 300481) could successfully access order 300401 which doesn't belong to them. This confirms the vulnerability at the exact location specified in the expected findings (routes.py lines 103-110).
